::: {.blockquote} In recent years economic growth has come to occupy an exalted position in the hierarchy of goals of government policy [...] At least in professional economic discussion, we need to give a definite and distinctive meaning to growth as a policy objective. Let it be neither a new synonym for good things in general nor a fashionable way to describe other economic objectives. Let growth be something it is possible to oppose as well as to favor, depending on judgments of social priorities and opportunities. ::: ::: {style="font-size:1.2rem;text-align:right;font-family:'Roboto Slab';"} James @tobin:1964 ::: ## Beyond GDP initiatives {.smaller} - Even though many aspects of the living standard correlate with GDP, there are also some blind spots (informal sector and non-market production, environmental and health externalities, etc.). - GDP is not designed as comprehensive measure of prosperity and well-being. "Beyond GDP" initiatives aim to find additional indicators for [environmental and social aspects of progress]{.hl .hl-dred}. - In 2007, the EU commission organized a conference on "Beyond GDP" which led to a roadmap for the "EU 2020 Strategy". - Much attention for Stiglitz-Sen-Fitoussi Report in 2009 with 12 recommendations how to measure progress. - United Nations formally adopted 17 "Sustainable Development Goals" (or Agenda 2030) in their general assembly in 2015. ## The growth imperative {.medium} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="20%"} ![](img/sdg8.png) ::: ::: {.column width="80%"} - Growth is an important goal in economic policy - *Magic square of economic policy* promotes high GDP growth (besides low inflation, high emplpoyment, and balanced trade) - UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDG): "Promote inclusive and sustainable economic growth, employment and decent work for all" - More specifically, "sustain per capita economic growth in accordance with national circumstances and, in particular, [at least 7 per cent]{.hl .hl-dred} gross domestic product growth per annum in the least developed countries" ::: ::: ## Rule of 70 {.medium} We often underestimate the power of growth! How long does it take for a variable [to double]{.hl .hl-dred} with a specific growth rate? The rule of 70 is a good approximation. Just divide 70 by the annual growth rate: $$ \Delta = \frac{70}{g} $$ Even with a moderate growth rate of 2%, total GDP doubles in 35 years. An annual growth rate of 7% would mean a doubling of production in only 10 years. ## Measuring GDP {.smaller} - 1937: Simon Kuznets presented the modern concept of GDP to US Congress following the Great Depression, warning that it is not a measure of national welfare. - 1953: System of National Accounts (SNA) aims to harmonize measurement of GDP across the globe. - 1995: European System of Accounts (ESA) is used by member states of the European Union (latest adaption 2010) - Three calculations: output, expenditure, and income approaches - GDP is not entirely exact: some components have to be estimated (e.g. tip, underground economy) - GDP has methodological gaps and some arbitrary definitions of what is productive, e.g. it includes childcare by nannies but not by parents. ::: {.aside} Short read: [Economist: Why GDP is so difficult to measure?](https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2016/01/27/why-gdp-is-so-difficult-to-measure) ::: ## GDP growth across the globe {.smaller} ```{r worldbank} #| echo: false #| results: 'asis' library(tidyverse) library(MetBrewer) load("data/worldbank.RData") # Create 7% p.a. series synt <- data.frame(country = "7% growth p.a.", year = 1989:2021, value = 1) |> mutate(index = 1 * 1.07 ^ (row_number() - 1)) # Create index (1989 = 1) plotdat <- gdp |> mutate(index = NY.GDP.MKTP.KD / NY.GDP.MKTP.KD[year == 1989], .by = country) |> bind_rows(synt) |> mutate(country = fct_reorder2(country, year, index)) p1 <- plotdat |> ggplot(aes(x = year, y = index, group = country, color = country)) + geom_line(size =0.9) + geom_point(data = plotdat |> filter(country == "China", year %in% c(1996,2004,2011,2019)), shape = 21, size = 3, show.legend = F) + geom_text(data = plotdat |> filter(country == "China", year %in% c(1996,2004,2011,2019)), size = 3, vjust = -1, hjust = 1, show.legend = F, aes(label = glue::glue("{year}: >{round(index,0)}x"))) + scale_color_met_d("Archambault") + labs(x = NULL, y = NULL) + theme_minimal() + theme(legend.title = element_blank(), legend.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA), legend.position = c(0.2, 0.75), panel.grid.minor = element_blank()) ``` ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} [Linear scale (1989 = 1)]{.secfont} ```{r linear} #| echo: false p1 + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::number_format(suffix = "x"), breaks = c(1, 2, seq(4,16,4))) ``` ::: ::: {.column .fragment} [Logarithmic scale (1989 = 1)]{.secfont} ```{r log} #| echo: false p1 + scale_y_log10(labels = scales::number_format(suffix = "x"), breaks = c(1, 2, seq(4,16,4))) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.aside} Source: World Bank ::: ## Reeeally long-term growth of GDP {.smaller} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} [Linear scale]{.secfont}

![](img/gdp_growth_long.png){fig-align="center"} ::: ::: {.column} [Logarithmic scale]{.secfont}

![](img/gdp_growth_long_log.png){fig-align="center"} ::: ::: ::: {.aside} Source: [Our world in data](https://ourworldindata.org/economic-growth) ::: ## Why do some economies grow and others don't? {.medium} ![](img/korea.jpg){height="500" fig-align="center"} ::: {.aside} Related reading: @crespo:2020 ::: ## Reasons for differences in economic growth {.medium} Economists historically focus on the "factors of production", like physical capital and human capital to explain differences in growth [@mankiw:1992; @young:1995]. The contemporary literature [@acemoglu:2019; @glaeser:2004] additionally highlights - culture (e.g., the willingness to trust and engage in trade with strangers) - geography (e.g., ease of transportation, resources) - institutions (e.g., welfare state regimes, democracy, legal rights) - (luck) ::: {.aside} Short read: [Asterisk Magazine](https://asteriskmag.com/issues/1/why-isn-t-the-whole-world-rich#1) ::: ## Which chart describes best what you want to show? {.medium} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ```{r abs} #| echo: false #| fig-height: 2.9 library(tidyverse) library(MetBrewer) library(scales) load("data/gdp.RData") gdp |> filter(unit == "Chain linked volumes (2010), euro per capita") |> ggplot(aes(x = time, y = values, group = geo, color = geo)) + geom_line(size = 1) + scale_color_manual(name = NULL, values = met.brewer("Juarez")) + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::number_format(prefix = "€", big.mark = ",")) + labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "GDP per capita in €") + theme_minimal() + theme(panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), legend.position = "bottom") ``` ```{r rates} #| echo: false #| fig-height: 2.9 gdp |> filter(str_detect(unit, "percentage")) |> ggplot(aes(x = time, y = values, group = geo, color = geo)) + geom_line(linewidth = 0.8) + geom_point(size = 0.2) + scale_color_manual(name = NULL, values = met.brewer("Juarez")) + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(scale = 1)) + labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "Growth rates of per capita GDP") + theme_minimal() + theme(panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(), legend.position = "bottom") ``` ::: ::: {.column .fragment} ```{r base} #| echo: false #| fig-height: 2.9 gdp |> filter(unit == "Chain linked volumes (2010), euro per capita") |> mutate(base = values / values[time == 2000] * 100, .by = geo) |> ggplot(aes(x = time, y = base, group = geo, color = geo)) + geom_hline(yintercept = 100, color = "black", size = 0.5) + geom_line(size = 0.8) + scale_color_manual(name = NULL, values = met.brewer("Juarez")) + labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "GDP per capita with anchor (2000 = 100)") + theme_minimal() + theme(legend.position = "bottom") ``` ```{r bars} #| echo: false #| fig-height: 2.9 gdp |> filter(str_detect(unit, "percentage")) |> ggplot(aes(x = time, y = values, fill = geo)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity") + coord_flip() + facet_wrap(~geo, ncol = 5) + scale_fill_manual(values = met.brewer("Juarez")) + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(scale = 1)) + scale_x_reverse() + labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, title = "GDP growth rates from 2000 to 2021") + theme_minimal() + theme(legend.position = "none", axis.text.x = element_text(size = 7), panel.border = element_rect(size = 0.1, fill = "transparent"), panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), plot.title.position = "plot") ``` ::: ::: # Show me your geometries!
